Dividends, Buybacks, and Capital Return Policy | Last Updated: {last_updated} | Source: SEC EDGAR 8-K, 10-Q, 10-K

Banking Sector Context
Banks like Cathay General Bancorp return capital to shareholders through two primary mechanisms:

1. Cash Dividends: Regular quarterly distributions representing a percentage of earnings
2. Share Repurchases: Buyback programs authorized by the Board to reduce share count and enhance per-share metrics

Key metrics for evaluating capital return include:
• Dividend Payout Ratio: Dividends ÷ Net Income (current {payout_ratio} within {payout_range})
• Retention Rate: 1 - Payout Ratio ({retention_rate} retained for growth)
• Organic Growth Capacity: ROTE × Retention = {organic_growth} sustainable equity growth ({organic_example})
• Total Shareholder Return: Dividend Yield {dividend_yield} + Share Price Appreciation

CRITICAL VALUATION INPUT: Through-Cycle NCO Analysis {period}

Mean NCO Rate: {mean} bps ({quarters} quarters from {period_desc})

  • GFC Peak: {gfc_peak} bps ({gfc_quarter})
  • COVID Peak: {covid_peak} bps ({covid_quarter})
  • Median: {median} bps (less volatile than mean)
  • Recent 4Q Average: {recent} bps (benign environment)

Source: FDIC Call Reports NTLNLSCOQR series (2008-Q1 through 2025-Q2)
Annual NCO Rate History ({range})

The table below presents {years} years of net charge-off data sourced from FDIC Call Reports (cert={cert}). This comprehensive dataset spans multiple credit cycles including the Global Financial Crisis, recovery period, and recent normalization.

{rows}
Year NCO Rate (bps) Credit Cycle Context

Data Source VERIFIED_OK
Source: {source}
Fields: {fields}
Extraction Date: {extraction}
Methodology: {methodology}
Verification: {verification}
Coverage: {coverage}

The through-cycle NCO rate of {through_cycle} bps is a critical input to our normalized ROTE and valuation framework. Current spot NCO rates significantly understate normalized credit costs, creating a false sense of profitability sustainability.

Provision Normalization

We use the through-cycle average of {through_cycle} bps as our baseline provision assumption for normalized ROTE calculation. This is conservative given CATY's commercial real estate concentration and recent portfolio growth.

{through_cycle} bps baseline

ROTE Sensitivity

Each 10 bps increase in NCO assumptions reduces ROTE by approximately {rote_sensitivity} bps. Moving from {spot} bps to {normalized} bps ({delta} bps increase) implies ~{rote_delta} bps reduction in normalized ROTE.

~{rote_sensitivity} bps / 10 bps NCO

P/TBV Impact

Each 10 bps change in NCO assumption impacts justified P/TBV by approximately {ptbv_sensitivity}x. The {delta} bps normalization implies ~{ptbv_delta}x reduction in fair value P/TBV multiple.

~{ptbv_sensitivity}x / 10 bps NCO

Recession Scenario

Using the GFC peak of {gfc_peak} bps as a severe stress scenario, normalized ROTE would fall to approximately {recession_rote}%, implying a P/TBV of ~{recession_ptbv}x at a {cost_equity}% cost of equity.

{recession_rote}% ROTE | {recession_ptbv}x P/TBV

Metric Spot (Q2'25) Normalized (42.8 bps) Delta
NCO Rate {spot_nco} {normalized_nco} +{delta_nco}
Implied Provision ~${spot_prov}M/qtr ~${normalized_prov}M/qtr +${delta_prov}M/qtr
Annual Impact - ~${annual_impact}M Pre-tax earnings drag
Normalized ROTE Impact - ~{rote_delta} bps Material compression
Fair Value P/TBV Impact - ~{ptbv_delta}x Multiple compression

Methodology Note
Provision Calculation: {through_cycle} bps × ${avg_loans}B avg loans ÷ 4 quarters = ${provision_calc}M/qtr
ROTE Sensitivity: Based on common equity tier 1 capital of ~${capital}B and {tax_rate}% tax rate
P/TBV Sensitivity: Derived from residual income model with {cost_equity}% cost of equity
Assumption: All other factors held constant; does not include NII or NIM impacts

metadata.purpose: NIM bridge and rate sensitivity analysis
metadata.data_policy: All material datapoints sourced from SEC filings with mandatory provenance
metadata.period_coverage: Quarterly through Q3 2025; structural beta series Q1 2022 - Q2 2025
metadata.units: USD millions unless noted; per-share in USD; ratios in percent or bps

template.template: Rate sensitivity and funding dynamics | Last Updated: {last_updated} | Source: Form 8-K (Q3 2025 results) + historical SEC 10-Q datasets

CATY entered Q3 2025 with Fed Funds anchored at {fed_end}%. Funding cost deceleration ({funding_change} bps q/q) paired with a modest asset yield uptick ({asset_change} bps) expanded net interest margin by {nim_change} bps. The deposit beta analysis below highlights liability sensitivity across the hiking cycle (Q1 2022 – Q2 2025).

subtext.template: Includes DDA dilution effect | Total deposits basis

template.template: CATY's institutional banking franchise (commercial deposit-focused) exhibits higher deposit betas than typical community banks. The IB-Only Beta of {ib_beta}% reflects sophisticated commercial depositors' rate sensitivity. The All-In Beta of {all_beta}% demonstrates benefit from stable DDA balances (averaging {dda_q2} in Q2'25 vs {dda_q1} in Q1'22).

Formula: Deposit Beta = (Δ Cost of IB Deposits) / (Δ Fed Funds Rate) Calculation: Δ Cost = {ib_end}% (Q2'25) - {ib_start}% (Q1'22) = {ib_delta}% Δ Fed Funds = {fed_end}% (Q2'25) - {fed_start}% (Q1'22) = {fed_delta}% IB-Only Beta = {ib_delta}% / {fed_delta}% = {ib_beta_ratio} ({ib_beta_pct}%)

Data Source VERIFIED_OK
Q1'22 Data: Form 10-Q, Accession 0001437749-22-011384, Filed May 9, 2022
Excerpt: "...cost of funds on average interest-bearing liabilities was {q1_cost_of_funds}%, and the cost of interest-bearing deposits was {q1_cost_ib}%..."
URL: View Q1'22 Filing

Q2'25 Data: Form 10-Q, Accession 0001437749-25-025772, Filed August 8, 2025
Excerpt: "...the average cost of interest-bearing deposits was {q2_cost_ib}%..."
URL: View Q2'25 Filing

Formula: All-In Beta = (Δ Blended Cost on Total Deposits) / (Δ Fed Funds Rate) Q1'22 Inputs: - Total Deposits (Avg): {q1_total} = {q1_ib} IB + {q1_dda} - Interest Expense: {q1_interest} ({q1_days} days) - Annualized Cost: ({q1_interest} × 365/{q1_days}) / {q1_total} = {q1_cost}% Q2'25 Inputs: - Total Deposits (Avg): {q2_total} = {q2_ib} IB + {q2_dda} - Interest Expense: {q2_interest} ({q2_days} days) - Annualized Cost: ({q2_interest} × 365/{q2_days}) / {q2_total} = {q2_cost}% Calculation: Δ Cost = {q2_cost}% (Q2'25) - {q1_cost}% (Q1'22) = {all_in_delta}% Δ Fed Funds = {fed_end}% - {fed_start}% = {fed_delta}% All-In Beta = {all_in_delta}% / {fed_delta}% = {all_in_beta_ratio} ({all_in_beta_pct}%)

Data Source VERIFIED_OK
Q2'25 Data: Form 10-Q, MD&A - Average balances, yields and rates (liabilities table)
Note: Total interest-bearing deposits (avg balance {q2_ib_balance}; interest {q2_interest}; rate {q2_rate}%) and Non-interest bearing liabilities: Demand deposits (avg {q2_dda_balance})
URL: View Filing

Q1'22 Data: Form 10-Q, MD&A - Average balances, yields and rates (liabilities table)
Note: Total interest-bearing deposits (avg {q1_ib_balance}; interest {q1_interest}; rate {q1_rate}%) and Demand deposits (avg {q1_dda_balance})
URL: View Q1'22 Filing

Item Details
FTE Disclosure CATY discloses NIM on both a reported (GAAP) and FTE basis in MD&A average balance tables.
Tax Rate Assumption FTE adjustments typically assume a statutory federal tax rate ({tax_rate}%) plus applicable state taxes. CATY's effective tax rate disclosed in income statement notes.
Tax-Exempt Securities Primarily municipal bonds. CATY's tax-exempt securities portfolio size and composition disclosed in securities footnote (Note 3 - Investment Securities).
Materiality FTE adjustments typically add {policy_range_low}-{policy_range_high} bps to reported NIM, depending on tax-exempt securities mix. Institutional investors analyze NIM on FTE basis for peer comparisons.

Data Availability Note
Status: FTE adjustment data not explicitly provided in source JSON (05_nim_decomposition.json).

Where to Find: CATY's 10-Q MD&A typically includes an "Average balances, yields and rates" table with FTE-adjusted NII and NIM columns. Check the table footnotes for FTE methodology disclosure.

Estimated FTE Impact: Based on peer banks with similar balance sheet structures (EWBC, CVBF), FTE adjustments typically range {range_low}-{range_high} bps. We estimate CATY's FTE adjustment at ~{fte_adjustment} bps, implying FTE NIM of ~{fte_nim}%.

Verification: To verify actual FTE adjustment, consult CATY 10-Q Q2'25 MD&A table directly at SEC EDGAR.

NIM {caty_nim}% {peer_nim_low}-{peer_nim_high}% {nim_rank}

Methodology Note
Data Sources: Peer deposit betas calculated from 10-Q filings (Q1'22 and Q2'25) using MD&A average balance tables. IB-Only Beta uses disclosed "cost of interest-bearing deposits" rates. All-In Beta computed from total deposit interest expense and average balances (IB + DDA). NIM data from Q2'25 10-Q MD&A NIM tables.

Assumptions: Fed Funds anchor periods standardized to Q1'22 ({fed_start}%) and Q2'25 ({fed_end}%). Daycount adjustments applied for quarterly interest expense annualization. CVBF and HAFC data estimated from publicly available investor presentations where 10-Q MD&A tables incomplete.

Verification Status: CATY and EWBC data VERIFIED_OK from SEC filings. CVBF and HAFC data ESTIMATED_FLAGGED (sourced from investor presentations, pending 10-Q verification).

{scenario3_name} {scenario3_fed_cut} {scenario3_deposit_delta} {scenario3_nim_impact} {scenario3_assumptions}
{scenario4_name} {scenario4_fed_cut} {scenario4_deposit_delta} {scenario4_nim_impact} {scenario4_assumptions}

Based on CATY's institutional deposit franchise and peer benchmarking, we estimate a down-cycle deposit beta of {assumed_beta}%, assuming symmetric pass-through behavior. This reflects: (1) commercial depositors' active treasury management, (2) limited deposit stickiness in rate-cutting cycles, and (3) competitive pressure in California commercial banking market.

Methodology Note
Scenario Analysis Assumptions: Estimated NIM impacts assume: (1) down-cycle beta of {assumed_beta}% (symmetric to up-cycle IB-Only beta), (2) asset repricing lags of {lag_low}-{lag_high} bps depending on loan mix and fixed-rate portfolio duration, (3) stable credit environment (no material provisioning drag), and (4) competitive deposit environment remains consistent with historical patterns.

Limitations: Actual NIM outcomes depend on: (1) Fed cutting cycle pace and depth, (2) CATY's asset-liability management actions (hedging, duration positioning), (3) loan portfolio repricing dynamics, (4) deposit competition intensity, and (5) macroeconomic conditions. These scenarios are illustrative and not predictive.

Data Sources: Historical deposit beta data from CATY 10-Q filings. Peer beta data from EWBC, CVBF, HAFC filings. NIM scenario ranges informed by historical bank NIM behavior during 2019 Fed cutting cycle (July 2019 - March 2020, -{prior_cycle} bps total).
If down-cycle beta < up-cycle beta (e.g., {sticky_beta}% vs {down_beta}%), deposit cost relief exceeds expectations.
If DDA balances stabilize or grow, all-in beta declines. However, DDA mix has trended down ({dda_start}% → {dda_end}% Q1'22 to Q2'25).

Funding Cost Relief {funding_impact} Deposit cost declined {funding_delta} bps QoQ ({funding_start}% → {funding_end}%) as CATY slowed deposit rate increases in anticipation of Fed pause.
Asset Yield Compression {asset_impact} Loan yields declined {asset_delta} bps QoQ ({asset_start}% → {asset_end}%) due to portfolio repricing and competitive loan origination environment.
Mix Shift (Est.) ~{mix_shift} No material shift in earning asset mix or deposit composition Q/Q. Mix effects negligible.
Daycount Effects ~{daycount_effect} Both Q1'25 and Q2'25 had 91 days (identical calendar daycount). No daycount distortion.
Net NIM Change {net_change} Sum: {funding_impact} (funding) {asset_impact} (assets) + ~{mix_shift} (mix) + ~{daycount_effect} (daycount) = {net_calc} bps NET BENEFIT, but {reported_nim_change} bps reported. Residual reflects rounding/precision.

KEY FINDING: BASE CASE (30 BPS) STAYS IN HOLD BAND

Applying the post-2014 90th percentile NCO of {nco_tc} bps resets normalized ROTE to {rote_norm}%, yielding a Gordon Growth fair value P/TBV of {ptbv_norm}x and target price of {target_norm}. That is {return_norm}% downside versus the {price_date} spot price of {spot_price}, which remains inside the -10%/+15% HOLD corridor. The 42.8 bps through-cycle mean is now treated as a stress guardrail (workpaper).

Normalization Methodology

Inputs:
- LTM Net Income: {ltm_net_income}
- Average TCE: {average_tce}
- Average Loans: {average_loans}
- LTM NCO: {ltm_nco} (below long-term average)

Formula:
1. Delta Provision = ({through_cycle_nco} - {ltm_nco}) × {average_loans} = {delta_provision}
2. Tax Effect = {delta_provision} × Tax Rate ({tax_rate}) = {tax_effect}
3. Normalized NI = {ltm_net_income} - {delta_provision} + {tax_effect} = {normalized_ni}
4. Normalized ROTE = {normalized_ni} / {average_tce} = {normalized_rote_reported} → {normalized_rote_adjusted}
5. Target P/TBV = ({normalized_rote_adjusted} - {growth_rate}) / ({coe} - {growth_rate}) = {normalized_ptbv}
The table below shows target P/TBV multiples under the BULL CASE scenario ({bull_nco} NCO, {bull_rote} ROTE) for different combinations of cost of equity (COE) and growth rate (g).

KEY STAT: Market-Implied Probability

Pr(Fair Value < {spot_price} Spot): {prob_below}

There is a {prob_below} probability that the fair value is below the current spot price of {spot_price} (market-implied weighting), indicating modest overvaluation. Conversely, there is a {prob_above} probability of upside above the current price. Wilson 95% upper bound uses {wilson_tail} tail probability for conservative HOLD.

CATY Residual Analysis

CATY's actual P/TBV of {actual_ptbv} is {discount_multiple} below the regression-fitted value of {fitted_ptbv}, based on its raw ROTE of {raw_rote}. This suggests CATY is trading at a slight discount relative to its current profitability.

However: This regression uses reported ROTE, not normalized ROTE. When we normalize CATY's ROTE to {normalized_rote} (base case with {through_cycle_nco} NCO via Gordon Growth), the fitted P/TBV drops to {normalized_ptbv}, which is below the current market multiple of {actual_ptbv}, supporting the HOLD rating.
Using the P/TBV mapping formula P/TBV = (ROTE - g) / (COE - g) and assuming g = {growth_rate}, we can back out the implied COE for each peer based on their current P/TBV multiples and ROTE.

CATY Predicted P/TBV from Mean COE

Using the mean peer COE of {mean_coe} and CATY's current ROTE of {raw_rote}, the predicted P/TBV is {predicted_ptbv}. CATY is currently trading at {actual_ptbv}, which is {mean_discount} below the peer-calibrated prediction.

This apparent "discount" disappears when we normalize ROTE to {normalized_rote} (base case via Gordon Growth), which implies a fair P/TBV of {normalized_ptbv} — well below the current {actual_ptbv}.

Base Case Calculation Step-by-Step

  1. Delta Provision: ({through_cycle_nco} - {ltm_nco}) × {average_loans} = {delta_provision}
  2. Tax Effect: {delta_provision} × {tax_rate} = {tax_effect} (benefit)
  3. After-Tax Delta: {delta_provision} - {tax_effect} = {after_tax_delta}
  4. Normalized NI: {ltm_net_income} - {after_tax_delta} = {normalized_ni}
  5. Normalized ROTE: {normalized_ni} / {average_tce} = {normalized_rote_reported} → {normalized_rote_adjusted} (Gordon Growth adjusted)
  6. Target P/TBV (Gordon Growth): ({normalized_rote_adjusted} - {growth_rate}) / ({coe} - {growth_rate}) = {normalized_ptbv}
  7. Target Price: {normalized_ptbv} × {tbvps} = {target_price}
